15348d9870dcb74619e01542df059860:
Iranian leaders have repeatedly promised to destroy Israel, and the nuclear deal may give them the means to do so.
American Jews must choose between the survival of Israel and loyalty to the Democratic Party.
73% of Jewish Israelis believe President Obama did not look out for Israel's interests in negotiating the nuclear deal, and 76% believe Israel should fight to torpedo the deal in Congress.
The nuclear deal with Iran is a bad one, as it will allow Iran to have nuclear weapons after 10 years, purchase conventional weaponry in five years, and purchase ballistic missile technology in eight years.
Under the deal, Iran's breakout time will be one year in the best-case scenario and two to three months in the more realistic scenario.
The deal enables and encourages Iranian cheating, as it allows Iran to pre-approve inspections and delay them by up to 78 days.
Iran will receive hundreds of billions of dollars in unfrozen assets and sanctions relief by the beginning of 2016, allowing it to become a regional conventional military power and strengthen its terrorist proxies.
Israel has received a total of $124.3 billion in aid from the US since its founding, while Iran will receive up to $150 billion as an immediate signing bonus.
Hezbollah has over 100,000 missiles targeting Israel, and Hamas has thousands more.
The Iranian deal guarantees that Israel will have to face at least two wars in the next decade, a more deadly conventional war in the short term and a possible nuclear war in the long run.
Obama supporters are using loyalty to the Democratic Party to convince Jews and Democrats to vote for the deal.
American Jews have no excuses for not supporting Israel in this matter, unlike in the 1930s and '40s.
A two-thirds vote in both chambers of Congress is needed to override a presidential veto.
There are 54 Republicans in the Senate who will vote against the deal, and 13 Democrats need to be convinced to vote against it.
There are nine Jewish Democrats in the Senate, including Chuck Schumer, Ben Cardin, Richard Bennet, Richard Blumenthal, Barbara Boxer, Dianne Feinstein, Al Franken, Brian Schatz, and Ron Wyden.
Senator Schumer opposes the deal, but Barbara Boxer supports it.
There are 247 Republicans in the House who need 43 Democrats to abandon Obama to override a veto.
There are 18 Jewish Democrats in the House, including David Cicilline, Stephen Cohen, Susan Davis, Eliot Engel, Lois Frankel, Alan Lowenthal, Jerrold Nadler, Jared Polis, Alan Grayson, Jan Schakowsky, Brad Sherman, Debbie Wasserman Schultz, and John Yarmuth.
Four Jewish congressmen oppose the deal, while two support it.
70% of American Jews are strongly or somewhat strongly attached to Israel.
The American people and the Jewish community in the US are turning against the agreement as they learn more about it.
US Jews will not forgive a vote to strengthen Iran and its axis of evil while throwing Israel under the bus.
bfe891e819fa0bd185139af9836f72a7:
Benjamin Netanyahu believes that the Iran nuclear deal will be approved by Congress despite his opposition.
Netanyahu has refused to engage in talks with President Obama about security compensation for the Iran deal, believing that it would weaken his position.
Netanyahu believes that the passage of the Iran accord by a Democratic bloc will strengthen his hand, as Democrats will be desperate to mend fences with Jewish voters and donors.
Netanyahu sees fringe benefits in his strategy, believing that the fight over the Iran deal will weaken the Democrats with the American public overall.
Netanyahu believes that a Republican victory in November 2016 would result in a pro-Israel administration that would adopt a tougher attitude on the implementation of the Iran deal.
Skeptics believe that Netanyahu is ignoring the effects of lingering resentments in the White House and pent up anger among Democrats.
Netanyahu is overlooking the long lasting damage to the American Jewish community, which is now splitting between pro and anti-deal factions.
Netanyahu is banking on a Republican victory in 2016, despite his previous error in predicting the outcome of the last election.
6d395649f102b3230fcd4e47e243c5fa:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hosted two delegations of US congressmen from both sides of the aisle to argue against the Iran nuclear agreement.
Netanyahu asserted that it was a “moral duty” to thwart the agreement.
Netanyahu did not explicitly call on the legislators to vote against the agreement in Congress next month.
Most if not all Republican congressmen are likely vote against the agreement with Iran, while many Democrats are expected to back their president and the deal he has negotiated.
Netanyahu acknowledged that many if not all of the Democrats might find it hard to vote against Obama, the leader of their party and a strong advocate for the deal.
The atmosphere at both meetings was serious, with a focused Netanyahu making his case reservedly and patiently.
Netanyahu attaches great importance to his meetings with American congressmen, especially with the Democrats.
Netanyahu met the groups for about an hour and a half each, and pointed out what he believes are the fatal weaknesses of the accord with the help of a marker and a white board.
Hoyer and McCarthy issued a joint statement of support for Israel, which hails America’s funding of the Iron Dome missile defense system but doesn’t mention the Iran deal.
da44b4ea3b252a17a199774911fcc3df:
The nuclear deal with Iran will allow the U.S., Israel and other countries to confront Iran’s support for terrorism and violations of human rights.
The agreement with Iran could allow the U.S. to increase its attention on “other aspects of Iranian behavior that give us serious problems.”
The deal will give the U.S. more freedom of action in addressing Iran’s support for Hezbollah and Houthi rebels in Yemen and its detainment of four American prisoners.
The agreement pulls Iran way back from the threshold of obtaining a nuclear weapon for a substantial period.
The Obama administration is facing stiff opposition to the agreement but is nonetheless notching victories among Democrats who could provide critical votes.
Jewish Americans are considered to be particularly skeptical of the deal, due to deep-seated fears about the threat posed by Iran and the vehement opposition from top leaders in the Israeli government.
Critics of the agreement allege its oversight mechanisms are weak, meaning Iran could easily cheat by evading inspectors’ prying eyes.
Critics also warn that the agreement sets the stage for Iran to obtain a nuclear weapon when many of the terms of the deal run out in 10 to 15 years, and that it stays silent on Iran’s other contested actions, such as the support for terror groups.
63076b68e6528528717d94cd09af5337:
A group of rabbis sent a letter expressing concern over the perception that the American Jewish community is united in opposition to the Iran nuclear deal.
The rabbis argue that the deal is the best available strategy to confront the specter of a nuclear Iran.
A recent poll from the L.A. Jewish Journal showed that 49 percent of American Jews approve of the Iran deal, while 31 percent disapprove.
The signatories to the letter include rabbis from the Reform, Conservative, and Orthodox movements.
The Orthodox Union, which represents most of the 10 percent of American Jews who call themselves Orthodox, is overwhelmingly opposed to the agreement.
2d81202aaa89901148f68fe8010757ca:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said Iran was advancing its nuclear program in order to destroy Israel.
Iranian Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei declared that the nuclear deal would not change the Islamic Republic’s belligerent attitude toward the U.S. or the Middle East.
Defense Minister Moshe Ya'alon said Iran was clearly intent on resuming its funding of terror organizations the moment the nuclear deal with the West went into effect.
U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said Khamenei’s vow to defy American policies in the region despite the deal with world powers over Tehran's nuclear program was "very troubling".
17a85594620b59d6f130dcef7edfd0ed:
Despite political attacks between the White House and the Israeli government, both sides express positive sentiments about future relations.
The rift over the Iranian nuclear deal may cause long-term damage to the US-Israeli strategic alliance.
The State Department believes that mistrust toward the Israeli government may erode coordination between the two governments.
The Israeli prime minister's partisanship, siding with the Republicans, has contributed to the schism.
Short-term damage to US-Israeli relations includes hindered information exchange on the Iran deal and US criticism of Israeli settlement expansion.
The United States may consider not vetoing a French proposal on Palestinian statehood at the UN Security Council.
Long-term repercussions include damage to the US perception of Israel's commitment to liberal democratic values.
Israel is now perceived as partisan and on the wrong side of US demographics.
Israel's image of a strong alliance with the United States is tarnished in the Arab world.
A fundamental change in Israeli policy is necessary, including recognizing the Iran deal and working with the Obama administration.
A security assistance package and coordination on peace policies are needed to strengthen the US-Israeli partnership.
bdc1add1a586d0d83806409c8fd88bd6:
The 60-day deadline for the US Congress to review the nuclear agreement between world powers and Iran is approaching.
Those opposing the agreement are currently an assured simple majority in Congress, including all Republicans and some Democrats.
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is trying to win over a sufficient number of senators and representatives to muster a two-thirds majority in each house to overcome a presidential veto.
Netanyahu's office in Jerusalem believes the prospects of garnering such a majority are nil.
Netanyahu wants to enlist the support of as many opponents to the deal as possible to obtain a "resounding moral majority."
Netanyahu argues that this moral majority represents the broad opposition to the agreement among the American public, which according to recent poll results encompasses nearly two-thirds of US citizens.
Netanyahu believes that the greater the majority in Congress against the agreement, the less the damage to the US-Israeli relationship.
Netanyahu is spurning all attempts by the US administration to promote a defensive compensation package designed to safeguard Israel's security.
Netanyahu is preparing for the day when he presents the administration with an itemized, full-price invoice for defense compensation.
Netanyahu views his moves in Congress not just as a strategic-diplomatic campaign, but as a personal mission thrust upon him by the historic circumstances in which he finds himself.
08085d4688ba4cab22a6108c189e6a1c:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is conducting a campaign against the nuclear deal with Iran, hoping to defy Capitol Hill arithmetic and inspire enough American lawmakers to thwart it.
Netanyahu has good reasons to be skeptical about the accord six world powers signed with Iran last month, fearing the cementing of the ayatollahs’ regime, increased terrorism, the establishment of Iran as a regional power, and perhaps even mushroom clouds over Israel.
Netanyahu's relentless and vociferous lobbying against the deal is causing severe climate change in the already-not-so-warm ties between Washington and Jerusalem.
The US administration was, is and will remain willing to provide Israel with military assistance, and has even pledged to be more generous than usual because of the Iran deal.
Israel’s aggressive lobbying, which includes speaking to US lawmakers about a “moral duty” to oppose the deal, is proving corrosive.
US President Barack Obama has openly criticized the Israeli government’s “unprecedented” effort to scuttle the deal, but insists that it will go unpunished.
Talks about upgrading Israel’s military capabilities are conducted by human beings, not robots. Israel’s interlocutors in the Pentagon will naturally not be as well-disposed toward the Jewish state as they would have been had Jerusalem not been fighting a bitter campaign seeking to kill the president’s most important foreign policy initiative.
Netanyahu believes that his public fight with the administration will lead Democrats to want to “mend fences with Jewish voters,” especially ahead of the 2016 presidential elections, and press the government to be especially generous to Israel when it finally discusses an increase in US military aid.
Netanyahu’s confrontation with the White House and his call on American Jews to oppose the deal is liable to have at least two other undesired side effects: turning support for Israel into a partisan issue and leading to serious rifts in the American Jewish community.
31450ada6f4783038e704e90cd402451:
A group of rabbis across religious denominations expressed concerns with the proposed nuclear agreement with Iran.
The rabbis believe the agreement will harm the short-term and long-term interests of the United States and its allies, particularly Israel.
If implemented, Iran will receive up to $150 billion without committing to changing its behavior, including denying basic human rights, calling for America's downfall and Israel's annihilation, and denying the Holocaust.
The deal will not subject Iran to a comprehensive inspections structure, allowing the regime to violate the agreement and develop a covert nuclear program.
The deal will lift key arms embargos, giving Iran international legitimacy to arm terror groups with conventional weapons and ballistic missiles in eight years.
The agreement entitles Iran to develop advanced centrifuges after 10 years, paving the way for Iran to develop nuclear weapons with virtually zero "breakout time."
The rabbis agree with assessments from leaders and experts in the United States and Israel that a better deal is possible and necessary.
The rabbis call upon Senators and Representatives to vote against the deal and support the opposition of many Jewish organizations.
The rabbis emphasize the critical responsibility to shape a better world for future generations and insist on a better deal.
6e251eaa3e6e79c91869c36440ed9dc4:
US President Barack Obama insisted that the recently negotiated agreement on Iran’s nuclear program “deals with the existential threat to Israel.”
Obama said the agreement “blocks every way, every pathway that Iran might take in order to obtain a nuclear weapon.”
Obama said once the nuclear accord was implemented, he expected “pretty quick” improvements in US-Israeli relations.
Obama stressed that the relationship between the United States and Israel is “sacrosanct” and “non-partisan.”
Obama defended his record on Israel’s security, saying that “even my fiercest critics” would say that there has been “unprecedented military cooperation” during his time in office.
Obama downplayed claims that lifting the sanctions on Iran would mean that Tehran had a windfall of money with which it could further fund terrorist activity.
Obama acknowledged the issue of Iranian support for the Lebanon-based terror group Hezbollah, which has previously sent hundreds of rockets into Israel.
Obama said that by removing the possibility of Tehran obtaining a nuclear weapon, it would be easier to then tackle other problematic aspects of Iran’s behavior.
Obama said the sanctions on Iran over its nuclear ambitions will be removed, but the sanctions that were imposed for its other infractions, such as its human rights record, would remain intact.
Congress has until late September to decide whether to reject the agreement. Obama has pledged to veto a rejection.
ae9dec31f9f76a9f0ed2436b8749dccf:
Israel does not object to Iran having a civilian nuclear program, only a military one.
The nuclear deal between Tehran and world powers allows Iran to retain infrastructure unnecessary for a peaceful nuclear program.
Iran will have the ability to make as many centrifuges as they want, enrich as much uranium as they want to whatever level that they want within 13 years under the deal.
The deal will put the Iranian Islamic state that practices terrorism worldwide on the threshold of an entire nuclear arsenal.
Obama said those who want a better deal typically mean that they want Iran not to have any nuclear program at all, even a peaceful one.
Obama compared tensions between the US and Israel over the nuclear deal to a family feud and said he expected quick improvements in ties between the longtime allies once the accord was implemented.
Sen. Tom Carper, D-Del., became the 30th senator to publicly back the agreement.
Obama has vowed to veto the resolution if it passes, and Democrats could hold off Republican efforts to override his veto if they get 34 votes.
The president encouraged skeptics of the agreement to “overcome the emotions” that have infused the debate and evaluate the accord based on facts.
Obama sought to refute criticism of the accord point by point.
He disputed the notion that Iran would funnel the bulk of the money it receives from the sanctions relief into terrorism.
He also said the agreement wasn’t built on trusting Iran’s government, which frequently spouts anti-American and anti-Israeli rhetoric.
934972d8831db5196cccb6fc2db2098e:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu approves of Iran using nuclear energy for civilian purposes.
Netanyahu opposes President Obama’s nuclear pact with Iran based only on its military implications.
Netanyahu believes the deal with Iran enables it to preserve and expand its vast nuclear infrastructure, which is unnecessary for a civilian nuclear program but vital to manufacturing nuclear weapons.
Netanyahu criticizes the deal for allowing Iran to enrich as much uranium as they wish at whichever level they wish, bringing Iran to the threshold of an entire nuclear arsenal.
Obama’s historic bargain with Iran eases economic sanctions on Iran in exchange for greater restrictions on its atomic energy capabilities.
Iran has vowed to permit more nuclear inspections and caps on its centrifuge and uranium stockpiles as part of the deal.
Obama is lobbying Congress to back the agreement’s language in a vote next month.
Lawmakers meet on Sept. 17 for a vote on a resolution either expressing approval or disapproval for the nuclear deal.
Democratic Sen. Jeff Merkley (Ore.) announced on Sunday that he is voting in favor of the controversial accord, making him the 31st senator backing Obama’s diplomatic agreement with Iran.
a906f240670be23f22ae2efdfe0a5534:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's public warmongering and confrontational policies played a major role in shaping the US strategy against Iran, leading to the nuclear deal.
Israel's previous policy was to avoid taking a leading role in the campaign against Iran's nuclear program and to coordinate all major strategic decisions with the US.
The Mossad was responsible for executing Israel's anti-Iranian policy, which included sanctions, covert operations, and exploiting ethnic divisions in Iran.
The Stuxnet computer virus, which damaged Iran's uranium-enrichment centrifuges, was a joint project of the Israeli and American intelligence communities, initiated and executed by the Mossad.
Netanyahu and Defense Minister Ehud Barak's public threats and military preparations led the Obama administration to believe that Israel was serious about a military strike, increasing anxiety and leading to the decision to negotiate a deal with Iran.
The US approach to the negotiations was hasty, resulting in a less than perfect deal with weaknesses in punitive measures and inspection clauses.
The deal paves the way for Iran to purchase better air defense systems, making a future military strike more dangerous.
Netanyahu should have coordinated his concerns with the US administration to influence the outcome of the deal and define red lines for substantial violations.
b0032fe43ecdbc45e85bbaf716aa8424:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu met with Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi in Florence on Saturday.
Netanyahu stated that Israel only opposes an Iranian military nuclear program, not one meant for peaceful purposes.
Netanyahu discussed the threat posed by Iran with Renzi, saying that Iran's pursuit of nuclear weapons is a far more serious threat than the Islamic State of ISIS.
Netanyahu warned that the deal with Iran will give Iran the ability to make as many centrifuges as they want, enrich as much uranium as they want to whatever level that they want, and put Iran on the threshold of an entire nuclear arsenal.
Netanyahu further warned that Iran will get hundreds of billions of dollars of sanctions relief and investments to fuel its aggression and terrorism in the Middle East, in North Africa and beyond that.
9c4d6cf7fcf66343110034322c2db0f6:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is expected to continue his campaign against the Iran nuclear deal.
President Barack Obama has secured enough congressional support to sustain a veto of any effort to block the Iran nuclear deal.
Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., announced that she was supporting the Iran nuclear deal, effectively ensuring that the deal will survive attempts in Congress to overturn it.
Netanyahu believes that a clear majority in the American public and in Congress agree with his opposition to the Iran nuclear deal.
Netanyahu has no regrets about his battle against the Iran nuclear deal, including his decision to speak before a joint session of Congress in March.
The sources close to Netanyahu said that the American people understand the dangers of the Iran nuclear deal to Israel and the United States.
The sources also insisted that the U.S.-Israel relationship is “strong” and that Netanyahu has “no doubt that the United States and Israel will continue to work together to address the enormous challenges confronting both our nations.”
Netanyahu may meet with Obama in Washington in November.
edd215c33552e4381c2d1f5b06f9a594:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu insisted most Americans agreed with Israel over dangers posed by Iran.
Netanyahu made no direct mention of President Barack Obama’s victory on Wednesday in securing enough Senate votes to protect the July 14 agreement in Congress.
Netanyahu suggested his efforts to persuade the U.S. Congress to reject Tehran’s nuclear deal were not futile.
Netanyahu said Israel’s message to ordinary Americans would continue to be that “Iran is the enemy of the United States – it declares that openly – and Israel is a U.S. ally.”
Netanyahu and other opponents of the pact say it gives Iran too much sanctions relief in exchange for an insufficient regime for inspecting Iran’s nuclear facilities.
Democratic Senator Barbara Mikulski said she would support the deal, bringing the list of backers in the Senate to 34 – enough to sustain Obama’s promised veto if the Republican-controlled Congress passes a disapproval resolution.
bf4e8c1cc786d344100dcfdf22ce1bb1:
A vast majority of Congress will reject the Iran nuclear deal next week, isolating those who support it from Israel.
The nuclear deal with Iran is not about Iran, but rather the future of the U.S.-Israeli relationship.
The Obama-Netanyahu divide will outlast them both, with Netanyahu being right about the deal being not the best but the worst.
Every aspect of Iran’s nuclear program will grow with time under the deal, creating more anger between Israel and America than between Iran and Obama.
The nuclear deal is not disarmament, arms control, or nonproliferation, as Iran keeps all of its nuclear facilities intact and will become more nuclear-capable.
The deal will ensure an end to sanctions and the strengthening of Tehran’s nuclear program.
The deal creates a force for independent risk taking in the Middle East, with Israel having the means to preempt an Iranian nuclear weapon and Saudi Arabia and other Gulf states turning to Russia for weapons.
a0133cbc1e61ef016d82318af40ab956:
Former Israeli Mossad spy chief Meir Dagan says Israel should stop criticizing the United States over the nuclear deal with Iran.
Dagan says "The problem is Iran, not President Obama."
Dagan has been a fierce critic of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s hard-line policies regarding Iran.
Dagan says Israel made a “strategic decision” to adopt a policy against the United States and “it is time to end it.”
Dagan is a retired military general who headed Israel’s secretive Mossad agency from 2002-2011.
6006d5d2319cd87f89aa15bdc803b79e:
The United States is not planning any bold new diplomatic initiatives after the Iran deal makes its way through Congress.
President Barack Obama seems more interested in repairing his tattered relationship with Israel, leaving the Palestinian issue to his successor.
Obama has spoken of boosting security cooperation and providing upgraded military hardware to make up for Israeli misgivings over the nuclear deal.
Netanyahu has vowed to continue fighting the Iran deal.
The United States is entering an election season in which Obama's Democratic Party can ill afford continued friction with Jewish Americans.
The problems dividing Israel and the Palestinians seem oddly resistant to negotiation and mediation.
The Palestinians seek all of the West Bank, east Jerusalem and the Gaza Strip for an independent state.
Israel has no intention of accepting the principle of a "right of return" of refugees who fled its territory in 1948.
President Mahmoud Abbas has hinted in recent weeks at retiring or canceling the existing 1990s peace deals.
Palestinian officials say US Secretary of State John Kerry called Abbas over the weekend and promised to meet on the sidelines of the UN General Assembly at the end of the month.
8f068cea7824aa9e5b728525562262e9:
Israeli security institutions do not perceive the Iran nuclear deal as a bad one, unlike the Israeli government.
Israel's security institutions believe the Iranian nuclear programme will continue to pose a threat to Israel's national security and doubt Iran will abide by the nuclear deal.
Israel's Defence Minister Moshe Yaalon believes the deal is a "historic mistake" and supports military options against Iran if it violates the deal.
Mossad, Israel's intelligence agency, believes the Palestinian cause is the real threat to Israel's national security, not Iran's nuclear programme.
Israel's Chief of Staff Gadi Eisenkot has appointed a committee to study the option of a military strike against Iran.
Israel is concerned about Iran's development of 2000-kilometre range missiles, which could reach Israel.
Israel anticipates Iran will increase its support to Shia militant groups in the Middle East, especially Hizbullah.
Israel has presented a list of military-related demands to the United States, including an increase in annual military aid from $1.3 billion to $4 billion.
Israel is also seeking military support from outside the United States, such as the Dolphin-class submarines deal with Germany.
2c9d7d89b218d96c4c135082b57d4d98:
President Obama has the 34 votes to override any Congressional objections to the Iranian nuclear deal and is well on the way to being able to prevent any vote at all, if he can achieve the 41 votes needed for a filibuster.
Israeli Prime Minister Binyamin Netanyahu intends to keep fighting against the Iran agreement despite the fact that it will pass Congress.
Netanyahu said that Israel must be mindful of its traditional allies, chiefly the United States, and that the American public understand the fact that Iran is an enemy of the United States.
Polls show that most Israelis oppose the Iranian nuclear deal.
Netanyahu’s campaign against the Iranian nuclear deal has deepened tensions between the US and Israel to one of the highest levels in recent history.
Netanyahu’s speech in Congress last March was a bad decision, according to an official from the pro-Israel lobby AIPAC.
Former Israeli Knesset member Dov Lipman said that Netanyahu has made serious mistakes in his campaign against the Iranian nuclear deal.
Some Israeli analysts say that Netanyahu will not give up his fight against the Iranian nuclear deal for several reasons, including security issues, political purposes, and his belief that the deal is a colossal mistake.
fcf75a2e658acd80cb619bc51bbc38d6:
Israel is reassessing its approach to the Syrian conflict due to increased Russian involvement in support of President Bashar al-Assad.
Israel has previously fired across the Golan Heights in response to spillover shelling or to bomb advanced arms suspected to be transferred to Hezbollah.
U.S. and regional reports indicate that Moscow's diplomatic and logistical support for Assad is shifting into major military backing, raising concerns about potential clashes between Israel and Russia.
Israel's Intelligence Ministry director-general, Ram Ben-Barak, acknowledges the potential ramifications of Russian intervention and the need for new rules of engagement.
Amos Gilad, senior adviser to Israeli Defence Minister Moshe Yaalon, confirms that Russia is entering into active intervention in Syria, but the extent of its involvement remains unclear.
Israel is communicating with Russia to avoid unintended confrontations between their forces, but the nature of this communication is not specified.
Israel has sought to stay out of the Syrian civil war, intervening only when fired upon or to prevent Hezbollah from gaining advanced weapons.
Past Israeli strikes in Syria have resulted in the deaths of Syrian troops and Hezbollah fighters.
Moscow has reaffirmed its military backing for Damascus but denies any current participation in military operations in Syria.
U.S. authorities have detected signs of Russia preparing for deployment of heavy military assets in Syria.
Israeli air force ex-general Amos Yadlin believes that Israel and Russia are unlikely to clash in Syria due to different areas of interest and cautious approaches.
Israel is expected to carefully assess risks and avoid air strikes where Russians might be present.
U.S. officials share Yadlin's assessment but caution that nothing is foolproof.
Israel may face challenges in distinguishing between Russian and Syrian aircraft due to similar models and Soviet-supplied equipment.
d63948502ffe285b17e70a7ca5c5b489:
Israel is reassessing its approach to the Syrian conflict due to increased Russian involvement in support of President Bashar Al Assad.
Israel has previously conducted military operations in Syria in response to spillover shelling or to prevent advanced arms from reaching Hezbollah.
The U.S. and regional reports indicate that Russia's support for Assad is shifting into major military backing, raising the prospect of accidental clashes between Israel and Russia.
Israel's Intelligence Ministry director-general, Ram Ben-Barak, acknowledges that Russian intervention in Syria may necessitate new Israeli rules of engagement.
Israel is communicating with Russia to avoid unintended confrontations between their forces.
Israel has sought to stay out of the Syrian civil war, intervening militarily only when fired upon or to prevent Hezbollah from gaining advanced weapons.
Past Israeli strikes in Syria have killed Syrian troops and Hezbollah fighters.
Russia has reaffirmed its military backing for Damascus but has not confirmed participation in military operations in Syria.
The U.S. has detected "worrisome preparatory steps" by Russia, including the transport of prefabricated houses to a Syrian airfield.
Israel and Russia are unlikely to find themselves pitted against each other in Syria as they have different areas of interest.
Israel is expected to be cautious in carrying out air strikes in Syria to avoid harming Russian forces.
78cab62748ba638063e0d08ecd226eb3:
Israel is reassessing its approach to the Syrian civil war due to increased Russian presence.
Israel has previously retaliated to attacks in Syria by targeting weapons depots and military convoys.
Israel is putting plans in place to avoid an accidental confrontation with Russia.
Ram Ben-Barak, director-general of Israel's Intelligence Ministry, said that Russian intervention in Syria could necessitate new Israeli rules of engagement.
Amos Gilad, senior adviser to Israeli Defense Minister Moshe Yaalon, said that the West and Russia are trying to unite against the Islamic State.
Gilad said that it is still too early to know how extensive Moscow's military involvement in Syria will be.
Gilad said that Israel is communicating with Russia to head off any unintended confrontations between their forces.
Amos Yadlin, the Director of Tel Aviv University's Institute for National Security Studies, predicted that Israel and Russia are unlikely to find themselves pitted against each other in Syria.
Yadlin said that Israel will be very careful to avoid attacking any site in Syria where Russian forces may be present.
d5cf4e27ec34b95b8d03dcc9b3c7aa31:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin in Moscow to discuss Putin’s support for the Assad regime in Syria.
Netanyahu will talk with Putin about “the stationing of Russian forces in Syria,” and “present the threats posed to Israel as a result of the increased flow of advanced war materiel to the Syrian arena and the transfer of deadly weapons to Hezbollah and other terror organizations.”
Putin pledged to continue military support for the Syrian government led by Bashar Assad.
U.S. State Department spokesman John Kirby said that the Russian military has had “increased activity” in Syria in the last few days.
5338ae3c10103b88b8a8b5cbec553dd3:
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will travel to Russia next week to speak with President Vladimir Putin about the deployment of Moscow’s forces to Syria and the threats to Israel caused by weapon deliveries to Damascus.
Netanyahu will discuss the dangers Israel faces if Hezbollah and other terror groups obtain Russian advanced weapons shipments.
Israel opposes Syrian President Bashar Assad’s regime, but has mostly sought to avoid being dragged into the conflict in neighboring Syria.
Russia has recently stepped up military aid to Damascus, despite protestations from the US and elsewhere.
Israel has expressed fears that the nuclear deal reached between six world powers, including Russia, and Iran could see money freed up as sanctions are lifted flowing to Hezbollah and other terror groups.
Relations between Israel and Russia have been negatively affected by Moscow’s willingness to sell military equipment to Iran.
The US has also expressed its concern to Russia regarding an alleged recent increase in military buildup in Syria.
US Secretary of State John Kerry Tuesday made a third phone call to his Russian counterpart, in which he warned that aid to the Syrian regime would only prolong the conflict in the war-torn country.
b7f672fe5879473aee5281901bce7b8c:
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu will visit Russia next week for talks with President Vladimir Putin on the expanding Russian military presence in Syria.
Netanyahu will present the threats to Israel emanating from the increased flow of advanced weaponry to the Syrian arena and from the transfer of lethal weaponry to Hezbollah and other terrorist groups.
Moscow has come under international pressure to explain its moves in Syria, where the Kremlin has been supporting Syrian President Bashar al-Assad in a 4-year-old civil war.
On Monday, two U.S. officials said Russia had positioned about a half dozen tanks at an airfield at the center of a military buildup in Syria.
Western officials and a Russian source said last week that Russia was sending an advanced anti-aircraft missile system to Syria in support of Assad.
Worried about accidentally coming to blows with Russian reinforcements in Syria, Israeli officials said last week they were in contact with Moscow.
The United States is using Syrian airspace to lead a campaign of air strikes against Islamic State. A greater Russian presence raises the prospect of the Cold War superpower foes encountering each other on the battlefield.
Russia has said it will continue providing military supplies to Syria and that its assistance to the Syrian army is in line with international law.
The Syrian civil war, in which about 250,000 people have died, has caused nearly half of Syria's prewar population of 23 million to flee, with many thousands attempting to reach Europe.
e269adc84613a1396a1f7139d12d01cf:
Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu visited Moscow to discuss Russia's provision of weapons to Syria and the risk of these weapons reaching Hezbollah.
Hezbollah is a Lebanese Shia militant group assisting the Syrian military in its war against terror groups.
Israel and Russia aim to prevent unintended clashes between the Israeli military and Russian forces stationed in Syria.
Israeli Chief of Staff Gadi Eizenkot may accompany Netanyahu on his trip to Moscow.
e95e81e443ef9856b7b4aa0d5eb8ffa8:
Israel and Russia agreed on a mechanism to avoid military confrontations between the two countries in Syria.
Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said that the mechanism is to prevent misunderstandings between IDF forces and Russian forces.
