China may attempt to modernize Iran's military, which could challenge the effectiveness of the US pivot to Asia policy.
Saudi Arabia is concerned about Iran's reemergence on the regional and global scene, as it could incite the quest for regional hegemony.
China may act as a mediator between Saudi Arabia and Iran, as it has good ties with both countries.
326eff2a6f8ad33b883629259efdf23e:
Iran's potential gas supplies to Georgia will have political, not economic, context for Tehran, according to Vagif Aliyev, head of the Investment Department of State Oil Company of Azerbaijan.
Azerbaijan is the main gas supplier to Georgia, with a 77.9 percent share of total imports.
SOCAR, the State Oil Company of Azerbaijan, has become the largest taxpayer in Georgia over the past five years.
Georgia and Azerbaijan have signed an agreement on gas deliveries until 2030.
Azerbaijan exported 1.5 billion cubic meters of gas to Georgia in Jan.-Nov. 2015.
Gas from Azerbaijan to Georgia is delivered via the Baku-Tbilisi-Erzurum gas pipeline and a pipeline that passes through Azerbaijan's Gazakh district.
Iran's possible gas supplies to Georgia could be on a small scale, according to Aliyev.
Iran currently exports gas to Turkey, Nakhchivan, and Armenia.
8b367086e7fa450578a801de4c153053:
Afghanistan is willing to import one million metric tons per annum of gas oil from Iran.
Iran is currently exporting 200 thousand metric tons of gas oil to Afghanistan.
Afghanistan is also seeking 200 thousand metric tons of LPG from Iran.
The prices of oil products and LPG will be discussed between Iran and Afghanistan.
Afghanistan used to receive $100 for each metric ton of gas oil imported from Iran with no privilege over other countries, but the issue is going to be amended.
6340b07bb22f840cbf2fde2e842159cf:
Georgia is considering replacing Russian gas with gas from Azerbaijan.
Georgia is discussing with Azerbaijan's State Oil Company (SOCAR) and Russia's Gazprom to replace Russian gas with Azerbaijani gas.
Azerbaijan is the main supplier of gas to Georgia.
Russian gas deliveries to Georgia are carried out only in the form of payment for its transit to Armenia.
Georgia is discussing with Gazprom the possibility for the Russian side to pay for gas transit to Armenia in money.
Georgia's gas needs are growing every year.
It will be impossible to completely replace the Russian gas with Azerbaijani gas.
Georgia can compensate the remaining volumes through the direct supplies from Russia.
The possibility of such supplies was also discussed at the talks with Gazprom.
Currently there is no infrastructure for gas supplies from any third country.
In the long-term, Georgia is interested in gas supplies from Iran.
Azerbaijan sells gas to Georgia at a very competitive and favorable price.
No agreements with Gazprom and SOCAR have been reached yet.
8fb5f7d10513ccadc262d335e9b0a53a:
Iran's oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zanganeh announced Czech Republic's interest to import natural gas from Iran.
Zanganeh said that exporting gas to Czech Republic by pipe is not possible now, but Iran has an incomplete unit of LNG, so the Czech side may sign a long-term contract with Iran for importing Liquid Natural Gas (LNG) or cooperate in its investment.
Zangeneh expressed Iran's interest for cooperation with Czech Republic in the sector of underground reservation of gas.
Zangeneh underlined that Czech companies may have cooperation with Iran as investors and not contractors.
Czech companies can cooperate with Iranian companies in transferring technology, manufacturing goods and equipment of oil industry and also investing in the petrochemical industry.
Volume of trade exchange between Iran and the Czech Republic in the first five months of the Iranian year (started March 2015) stands at $12.3 million.
ff65b14fe6f954914681a879ec2ba5fc:
Iran prioritizes exporting gas to regional countries in the post-sanctions era.
Iran will export 65 million cubic meters of gas to Iraq per day, increasing in the warm season.
Iran will export 30 million cubic meters of gas to Baghdad province and 35 million to Basra.
Iran is not suing Pakistan for lack of commitment regarding the completion of the Peace Pipeline, preferring friendly relations.
Iran will not hold negotiations with Turkey to boost gas export until the current lawsuit filed by Turkey against Iran receives a court ruling.
Iran-Oman underwater gas pipeline will be completed in 1.5 years.
Iran will export 28 million cubic meters of natural gas per day to Oman, with part consumed by Oman and the rest turned into LNG and exported on behalf of Iran.
Iran will hold negotiations with Indian customers in the near future.
Iran is producing about 700 mcm/d of gas and plans to increase this volume to 1,300 mcm/d by 2020.
59f882f368f4ac693b909d1fb95df9b2:
Iran will start negotiations on using Oman's unused LNG capacity within the next ten days.
Iran and Oman discussed the international crude oil market, gas export, and oil market.
Iran and Oman agreed to construct a pipeline to carry 1 billion cubic feet or 28 million cubic meters of gas per day at an annual volume of 10 billion cubic meters.
The value of exporting 10 billion cubic meters of gas per year will be around 1.5 to 2 billion dollars annually.
National Iranian Gas Export Company and Oman will start negotiating with foreign firms to use the unused capacity within the next 10 days.
Iran and Oman discussed financing the pipeline project.
Oman has always been ready to cooperate with OPEC, but OPEC lacks a clear stand on managing the oil market.
24719b20cfc624c1c980eb5ea6759fc7:
Iran plans to launch 16 oil refining projects, worth 33 billion euros, to surpass Saudi Arabia as the biggest oil refiner in the Middle East.
Iran's oil refining capacity is currently 1.85 million barrels per day (mbpd).
Iran plans to build 12 medium and large crude oil and gas condensate refining units, implement fuel oil output reduction projects at Bandar Abbas and Abadan refineries, revamp Isfahan and Abadan refineries, and boost crude oil and oil products transfer capacity.
Once the projects are completed, Iran's oil refining capacity will increase by 1.29 mbpd and reach 3.1 mbpd.
Saudi Arabia's oil refining capacity has been declining over the past five years from 2.8 mbpd in 2010 to around 2.1 mbpd in 2015.
Iranian laws stipulate that private sector and foreign investors should account for 80 percent of those putting funds into the oil refining projects in the country.
1bf81dc8bc8618dec29e6c8f9895bb64:
Hellenic Petroleum, Greece’s biggest oil refiner, agreed to buy crude oil from the National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC).
Hellenic Petroleum was a major buyer of Iranian crude before sanctions were imposed on Tehran in 2011.
Hellenic Petroleum will start buying oil from Iran immediately and will settle its multimillion euro outstanding debt to NIOC.
Hellenic Petroleum is estimated to owe Iran around $550-600 million for oil it bought before the sanctions.
Iran believes Greece could be a conduit for re-entering Europe’s oil market.
Iran used to sell as much as 800,000 barrels per day (bpd) to European refiners in Italy, Spain and Greece before the sanctions were imposed.
Tehran ordered a 500,000-bpd increase in its oil output, of which 200,000 bpd will go to Europe, after the sanctions were lifted on Saturday.
fc3608d51291ce4fcee7bf45ec13a0f7:
Iran has signed a deal with Russia's Lukoil for two exploration projects in Khouzestan province.
Lukoil will explore hydrocarbon reserves in Dasht-e Abadan and the northern parts of the Persian Gulf.
The contract is worth about $6 million, and Lukoil has already started work on the projects.
Lukoil and Statoil had previously won a deal to explore in Iran in 2003, but pulled out in 2011 due to sanctions.
Lukoil President Vagit Alekperov has said that the company is interested in returning to Iran to develop Azar oil field.
e45937b45d4983f961bf7a1bd49da58f:
Iran is actively seeking new opportunities for the production and exports of natural gas.
Iran is developing liquefied natural gas (LNG) facilities to commence shipments to Europe in two years.
Iran has been in talks on the construction of floating LNG facilities with several European companies, including the Golar LNG international operator of LNG carriers.
The project is due to be implemented in less than two years.
517f9a1e1b0c6acff581dda09aea4774:
Iran's gas industry requires massive investments to meet European and global demand.
Iran currently produces only 160 billion cubic meters of gas annually due to technological and financial constraints.
Iran supplies less than 1 percent of global natural gas exports.
Iran's natural gas deposits are estimated at 34 trillion cubic meters.
Iran's gas could contribute to European energy security, given the recent shift in relations between Iran and the EU.
The existing Iran-Turkey pipeline could provide up to 7 billion cubic meters of gas per year to Europe in two to three years.
Plans exist to build a Persian Pipeline with a capacity of up to 40 billion cubic meters per year to transfer Iranian gas to Europe.
Building LNG export terminals would be an important step for ensuring Iranian gas supplies to Europe.
bfef6d4a2f49d34e25ac67b01651f82f:
French energy giant Total will sign a contract with Iran to buy 150,000 to 200,000 barrels of crude oil a day.
The deal will be signed at the French presidency later Thursday.
Iran has decided to increase its oil production to 500,000 barrels a day.
The price of crude oil is currently around $32 (29 euros) a barrel, about 70 percent less than it was in June 2014.
Iran currently produces 2.8 million barrels a day, about a million of which are destined for export.
Total has other French projects in the pipeline with Iran.
74ea59015ce9a3695ee6060a61977546:
Iran is unlikely to export its own gas to Europe for the next ten years.
Iran uses the gas extracted to increase oil production by pumping gas into layers to maintain pressure.
Iran has huge potential in terms of gas production, but most of the gas produced is pumped back into the well.
Iran will be more engaged in gas processing, rather than its export in the next years.
Iran and Oman have very close and trustful relations, and Iran will supply 10 bcm of gas annually to Oman through a pipeline.
The European market is not attractive for Iran in terms of sales of LNG.
Iran plans to launch seven large complexes, each of which is designed to release 6-10 million tons of LNG annually.
98c3b46dd0e1357a4ce1dcd5009695ce:
Iran is willing to sell its gas to Europe but lacks pipelines to do so.
Iran has expressed interest in joining the Trans Anatolian gas pipeline project, but Azerbaijan has not discussed commercial supplies of Iranian gas via TANAP.
Iran's ambassador to Azerbaijan said Tehran is capable of joining major regional projects such as TANAP after the removal of sanctions.
LNG is probably Iran's best opportunity for exporting gas to Europe in the near future.
Iran has already developed an LNG plant by 50 percent, which is expected to become operational in 2018 with 10.5 million tons annual production capacity.
Iran is in talks with France, Germany and Belgium for construction of LNG tankers.
Iran will be able to attract investments to develop necessary infrastructure in energy sphere.
c707d2eb8c79368ea911b9d670e5f6b4:
Iran and Iraq's joint oil field project will be operational by the end of the Persian Calendar year.
The production of oil from North Azadegan and Yadavaran has increased by 75,000 and 85,000 barrels a day respectively.
The projects will be inaugurated following the Parliamentary elections in February.
The oil extracted from Iran and Iraq joint oil fields will reach 300,000 barrels a day next year and 550,000 barrels a day by the end of the next Persian Calendar year.
b13c22da24aa64beaf6fa1dd5bd50ad2:
Iran is on track to raise oil production by 500,000 barrels per day after the lifting of sanctions this month.
Iran has already sold 6 supertankers with additional crude to buyers in Europe and Asia.
Litasco, the trading arm of Russia's Lukoil, is set to become the first buyer in Europe since the lifting of sanctions.
Iran has promised to begin regaining market share lost during years of curtailed output after European sanctions on its oil industry were lifted this month.
Iran will also introduce a new heavy crude blend, West Karun, by the end of March or start of April to win back more customers.
Iran is expected to add barrels in an already oversupplied market where its rivals Saudi Arabia and Iraq have consistently raised production.
OPEC officials have said the markets have begun to rebalance as investment is being curtailed due to low oil prices.
11db43c0e6f2c7cd9cc83a072f4df5c5:
Lifting of international sanctions on Iran will lead to increased opportunities for Pakistan to promote bilateral trade and investment, and to re-initiate work on the many stalled projects agreed to in the past, including Iran-Pak Refinery project.
Iran-Pak Refinery project, to be constructed at Gwadar port in Balochistan at a cost of $4 billion, was shelved some years ago.
Pakistan has a total refining capacity to process around 400,000bpd or about 19MTPA of crude oil, against the current demand of 24MTPA.
Demand for oil products in Pakistan is expected to grow steadily at seven percent on year-on-year basis, according to recent studies.
Currently, there are seven oil refineries operating in Pakistan.
To meet fast growing demand of the POL (petroleum oils and lubricants) products it was planned by the government since long to set up new refinery projects, besides undertaking capacity expansion of the existing refineries.
Khalifa Coastal Refinery, of capacity 250,000bpd or 13MTPA, was approved by the ECC of the Cabinet in 2007 at a cost of $6 billion.
The Badin Refinery was planned in 1991, with a capacity of 35,000bpd extendable to 45,000bpd.
Indus Refinery Ltd, in private sector, of 93,000bpd capacity located near Port Qasim Karachi is another long-running project, which has not been completed as yet.
China and the UAE investors have shown interest in setting up oil refineries in Pakistan.
The first refinery to be established in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa is on cards based on indigenous crude oil, of initial capacity 20,000bpd to be doubled in the next phase.
c943d2bb928b6e61d0e5fa297d988422:
Turkey won an arbitration case against Iran in a gas dispute and will receive a 13.3 to 15.8 percent discount on gas purchased from Iran between 2011 and 2015.
Iran agreed to the discount only if the imported amount of gas was increased, which Turkey rejected.
Turkey approached the International Court of Arbitration in 2012, demanding that the price be lowered by 25 percent.
Turkey's state-run BOTAŞ Petroleum Pipeline Corporation sued Iran in 2014 over high gas prices and received a 16.5 percent discount and a $900 million payment from Iran.
Turkey's natural gas consumption reached a new high, with 235 million cubic meters burned on a daily basis last week.
Turkey consumed a total of 1.128 billion cubic meters of natural gas between Jan. 25 and Jan. 29, which is equal to an average consumption 235 million cubic meters per day.
Total annual natural gas consumption stood at 48 billion cubic meters in Turkey in 2014.
The Turkish Natural Gas Distributors Union Association (GAZBİR) downgraded their estimates for the coming year's annual consumption of natural gas from 51 billion cubic meters to 47.8 billion cubic meters.
f3a02eb69795abb9c591f2747a6d680a:
Iran says the International Court of Arbitration hasn't announced its final verdict on the country's gas dispute with Turkey.
Iran's deputy oil minister and NIGC managing director Hamidreza Araqi previously said that due to court's ruling in favor of Turkey, Iran will have to pay a compensation to the country.
According to the court's ruling, Iran should provide Turkey with compensation of 10-15 percent for the gas supplied to that country within 2011-2015.
In 1996, Iran and Turkey signed a 25-year deal on supplying 30 million cubic meters of gas to Turkey per day.
Turkey appealed to the International Court of Arbitration regarding the price on Iranian gas in March 2012.
Iran is Turkey's second supplier of gas after Russia, providing for one-fifth of the country's consumption.
506c2f98b17fa60cb998468703682e09:
Turkey complained to Iran about instability of gas supplies and overcharging.
The International Court of Arbitration ruled against Iran in its gas dispute with Turkey, ordering Iran to pay some $1bn in compensation for overcharging.
Iran must reduce the price of gas it exported to Turkey between 2011 and 2015 by 10-15 percent.
Turkey cannot put forward any requests by the next couple of years on reducing gas price or changing gas export formula.
Iran must supply Turkey with a about 10 billion cubic meters per year under a 25-year deal signed in 1996.
Iran had proposed doubling exports of its natural gas for a discounted price last year, but Ankara rejected the offer.
039f1afd8b6d54679b9bd5346477b066:
Iran may attach political importance to exporting gas to Europe to complicate the possible reapplication of sanctions against the country.
Iran's gas production potential is enormous, but the country faces formidable obstacles to gas exports.
Domestic residential demand for gas continues to grow, and gas is needed for reinjection into oil fields to keep up production.
Iran plans to build up a first class petrochemical industry and export electricity regionally instead of gas.
The current price environment in Europe does not help make it commercially viable to bring gas all the way from South Pars to the European markets.
Iran holds 17 percent of the world's proved natural gas reserves and more than one-third of OPEC's reserves.
Iran is the world's third-largest dry natural gas producer, after the US and Russia.
Iran's return to the global energy market will have profound repercussions for international markets.
Iran's barrels will add to an already oversupplied global oil markets and may drive down prices further.
Iran's current oil production is estimated to be around 2.8 million barrels per day (mbpd), of which about one million barrels are exported.
Free of sanctions, Iran plans to increase its oil export by 500,000 barrels per day, and then raise the figure by another 500,000 to two million barrels per day within a six month period at the next step.
76af919bb3bae960dc15f068a60598e5:
Iran's crude oil sales to Europe have reached above 300,000 barrels after the lifting of international sanctions.
Iran's oil exports recorded a high of more than 3 million barrels per day in 2011, but fell to a little more than 1 million bpd after sanctions were imposed in 2012.
Iran has ordered a 500,000 bpd increase in oil output after the nuclear deal with world powers was rubber-stamped last year.
Total will buy 160,000 bpd of crude oil from Iran to be delivered in Europe, as per a contract signed between the National Iranian Oil Co and Total.
Italy's Eni is interested in buying 100,000 barrels of crude oil from Iran and its representatives would visit Tehran in near future to discuss the contract.
Iran's oil minister said Italian refiner Saras was intent to buy 60,000 to 70,000 barrels of crude oil from Iran.
Iran is working on attracting foreign investors that have been frightened by sanctions and low by mitigating the terms it offers on oil development contracts.
The new contracts, comprising those in the upstream exploration and development sectors are expected to attract more than $40 billion in foreign investment.
Iran has put off a planned oil conference in London, which was due to have taken place in February to reveal its new contracts, until November.
e82332d5a8c92723b89064fa04fd9bb0:
Iran is currently exporting 300,000 barrels per day of crude oil to European countries.
Iran's National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC) will soon finalize a contract with the French Total to sell 160,000 barrels per day of crude oil to the company.
Total has indicated its readiness to take part in the development of South Azadegan oil field and Iran LNG project.
Officials of Italy's Eni have also indicated their willingness to work in the Iranian oil sector.
Italy's Saras refinery has demanded to buy between 60,000 to 70,000 barrels of Iran's crude oil per day.
Iran is putting finishing touches to the new format of its oil contracts, known as the Iran Petroleum Contracts (IPC), to attract more international investment in the country's oil sector.
Under the IPC, the National Iranian Oil Company will set up joint ventures for crude oil and gas production with international companies, which will be paid with a share of the output.
a097b3b306d4e61ea916c17e62bae0a2:
Iran sees gas export as profitable despite Qatar's heavy dumping.
Iran is producing most of its gas from joint fields, making any sort of export beneficial.
Qatar has been selling gas at a very low price in Indian and Pakistani markets.
Iran's South Pars gas field produced 95.18 billion cubic meters of natural gas in the first ten months of the current Iranian fiscal year.
Iran expects the South Pars gas field to produce 130 billion cubic meters by the end of the current fiscal year.
Iran is producing 420 million cubic meters per day of gas from South Pars, and the production level is projected to surpass 700 million cubic meters per day by late 2018.
South Pars contains 40 trillion cubic meters of natural gas.
Negotiations are still ongoing between Iran and Russia regarding the swap of gas.
No agreement has yet been made on the swap of gas between Iran and Russia.
Iran was an active participant in swap operations prior to the introduction of sanctions.
Iran is preparing to start gas swap with Russia for the first time.
Gazprom has offered gas supplies to Iran under a swap arrangement, delivering gas to Iran's northern regions and taking Iranian LNG in the Persian Gulf.
Iran has an LNG plant with 10.5 million tons of production capacity annually, which is expected to become operational by 2019.
9cb7ce8645dfb4837151c9ec94616f4b:
Iran plans to sell 300,000 barrels of oil per day to the European market.
Anglo-Swiss commodity trader Glencore has become the first Western company to deal in Iranian crude.
Iran plans to boost exports by 500,000 barrels per day in the coming months.
Iran has agreed on a deal with France’s Total to buy 160,000 bpd of crude oil from Iran to be delivered in Europe.
Italy’s Eni is interested in buying 100,000 bpd of oil from Tehran.
Italian refiner Saras is also interested in buying 60,000 to 70,000 bpd.
A tanker chartered by Glencore loaded 80,000 metric tons of fuel oil on Friday and is bound for Singapore.
Iran intends to raise more than $40 billion of foreign investment for its oil industry.
Additional crude from Iran could shatter the already fragile market.
Oil prices dropped to 12-year lows of less than $27 a barrel in January due to global oversupply.
A million bpd increase in Iran's oil exports can make prices fall by an additional 13 percent, or $3 per barrel.
6e1094986041d129d3408524180f2959:
Iran is considering increasing gas exports to Armenia fivefold.
Iran currently exports about one mcm of gas to Armenia daily.
The construction of new power lines can be a key factor of increasing Iranian gas supply to Armenia.
Iran and Armenia signed a contract for construction of the third power transmission line in August 2015.
The contract envisages the construction of a 275 kilometer-transmission line for two years.
This will increase the volumes of mutual supplies of electricity threefold.
64a16c21297d7cbfa632386a1672928c:
Iran has been producing 200 thousand barrels a day more oil since January 21.
The oil is being stored for later export to Europe.
Greece is likely to be the first receiver of the oil.
Iran has a contract to export 160 thousand barrels of oil a day to France's Total starting February 16.
Total is also going to start work on Iranian projects including the Sough Azadegan oil field and Iran LNG.
The Italian Eni is going to sign a contract with Iran during a near future visit of the company's representatives to Tehran.
Eni has requested a daily flow of 100 thousand barrels of oil.
The Italian Saras is also seeking 60 to 70 thousand barrels of crude per day from Iran.
4fd6e16061d8bf9c4cf84cbe0fea23e3:
Zamaninia said that all international regulations were applied in the oil export transaction.
The successful implementation of the JCPOA, the termination of the sanctions, the buying and selling of the oil products to and from Iran, and the insurance of this batch were all rings of the chain that led to this oil deal.
Iran is exporting 1,600,000 barrels of oil per day.
961f8f2f9ee35f79bd3952edbed1e9e1:
Iran’s oil minister said foreign oil companies that owe his country billions of dollars are likely to settle their debts in euros.
Greece’s Hellenic Petroleum, Italy’s Saras and Royal Dutch Shell owe Iran about $4 billion which will be paid back in euros.
Shell has said it was ready to settle its debts to Iran, but Greece’s Hellenic Petroleum is having trouble to pay Iran back.
Emirates National Oil Co, Japan and the Netherlands had started settling their debts to Iran’s central bank.
Iran wants to recover tens of billions of dollars it is owed by buyers of its oil in euros and is billing new crude sales in euros, too.
Iran will charge in euros for its recently signed oil contracts with firms including French oil and gas major Total, Spanish refiner Cepsa and Litasco, the trading arm of Russia’s Lukoil.
Iran favours the euro as the payment currency for its oil export contracts.
018f879d723f6295a84cff9aef275dd9:
Iran is currently exporting 1.3 million barrels of crude oil per day (bpd).
Iran plans to increase its oil exports to 1.5 million bpd by the start of the next Iranian year on March 20.
Iran aims to reach 2 million bpd of oil exports in the early parts of the next Iranian year.
Iran is also trying to increase production of gas and refined products, particularly petrochemicals.
Iran produced 35 million tonnes of petrochemical products in the nine months to December, of which 14.3 million tonnes were exported.
02513c72a378a921fd8ab3dd21a48094:
Iran plans to increase oil exports by one million barrels per day in six months.
The first Iranian oil shipment since the lifting of sanctions will leave this weekend, carrying four million barrels of crude to French, Russian and Spanish customers.
Iran is undercutting Saudi Arabia's oil prices by about a dollar per barrel to attract European customers.
Saudi Arabia is selling oil at a discount to Asia to counter the U.S. shale boom.
The global oil glut has led to concerns about losing market share and a shortage of storage space.
U.S. sanctions related to Iran's human rights and terrorism record remain in place, making it difficult for Iran to sell oil.
Many shipowners and insurers are hesitant to handle Iranian oil due to the sanctions and the use of the American financial system.
c053dc567f8e184d2e4b1049204a262d:
Iran has accepted the International Court of Arbitration's decision on discounted Iranian gas being sold to Turkey.
Iran will meet the decision by giving Turkey more gas or through cash payments.
Turkey and Iran had different views about the gas sales before, and the issue was brought to the arbitration court.
Turkey buys around 10 billion cubic meters (bcm) of gas from Iran and opened two separate cases against Iran in 2012.
The court ruled against Iran in its gas dispute with Turkey.
Specialists from Iran and Turkey have already come together to discuss the results of the arbitration ruling.
Iran's Oil Minister Bijan Namdar Zangeneh will visit Turkey soon to resolve the issue.
Turkey and Iran must decide within three months on the level of discount Turkey will receive on Iranian gas.
Iran needs to complete 2000 projects in the initial stage in the post-sanction era.
Iran has emerged as a new center of attraction for the world's largest economies after the removal of sanctions.
Iran's energy portfolio is up to $300 billion.
1b5a252d7a6d90f05bf21ca1460a946d:
French Total Company purchased two million barrels of oil from Iran.
Two Russian and Spanish companies purchased two million barrels of oil from Iran.
The Russian company will ship oil to its refinery in Romania.
Iran plans to increase its oil export by one million bpd in two phases in the post-sanctions era.
Iran has a contract to sell 160,000 barrels of crude oil to Total on February 16, 2016.
Italian Oil Companies of Eni and Saras are traditional customers of Iranian oil and will purchase oil in the post-sanctions era.
Iran intends to offer a discount to retake its European share from rivals.
Before the intensification of sanctions, Iran exported 500,000 bpd of oil to Europe, which later reduced to 100,000 bpd.
32b79568da9e4d281554828be53a4f12:
Iran has shipped crude oil to Europe for the first time in five years.
Iran has loaded several European tankers with oil, including 2 million barrels for France's Total and 2 million barrels for two companies in Russia and Spain.
Iran has signed a deal with French oil giant Total for daily export of 160,000 to 180,000 barrels of oil per day.
Iran's exports to Japan have increased by 34 percent since December of 2015.
Iran is seeking to gain at least 10 percent of Japan's market, which would mean a daily export of 350,000 barrels per day.
Iran's overall exports are set to substantially increase, from 1.3 million barrels per day (bpd) to 1.5 million bpd by mid-March, and to 2 million within a few months.
The National Iranian Oil Company (NIOC) is also seeking to step up its oil trade with other costumers, including China, South Korea, India and Turkey.
9ff1af90ad2e322870d46d3425daa0db:
Iran is poised to export its first oil shipments to Europe since international economic sanctions were lifted in mid-January.
Two million barrels of oil are being pumped aboard a tanker at Kharg Island in the Gulf, bound for French energy giant Total.
Another two tankers are preparing to ship a million barrels each to Spain's CEPSA and Lukoil of Russia.
Loading of the tankers would be complete within 24 hours.
In early 2012, the European Union and United States strengthened economic sanctions against Iran because of its controversial nuclear programme, forcing the Islamic republic to halt oil exports to Europe.
Since then, Asia -- mainly India and China -- have been the main market for Iranian oil.
Iran's nuclear agreement last July with world powers means that now that most of the sanctions have been lifted it can resume oil exports to Europe.
Last month, the National Oil Company said it had ordered production to increase by 500,000 bpd -- a move Tehran had long planned once the nuclear deal with world powers took effect.
When President Hassan Rouhani visited France in January, a deal was signed with Total to buy 160,000 bpd.
Oil prices rose on Monday with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate for March delivery climbing 57 cents to $33.01 per barrel from Friday's close.
3d2dd6b6b9dc853c8dbfc4863c9ae3d5:
Iran shipped its first cargo of oil to Europe since international sanctions ended.
The Suezmax vessel Distya Akula departed Iran's loading terminal at Kharg Island in the Gulf and was located on Saturday in the Gulf of Oman off the east coast of the UAE.
Iran is trying to rebuild its oil output after sanctions were lifted in January, with plans to boost production and exports by 1mn bpd this year.
Iran pumped 2.86mn bpd in January.
Iran is planning three initial shipments to Europe carrying 4mn barrels of oil with 2mn barrels going to Total and the rest to companies from Spain and Russia.
Total, Spanish refiner Compania Espanola de Petroleos and Russia's Lukoil all booked cargoes of Iranian crude to sail from Kharg Island to European ports.
The vessels included one very large crude carrier, a tanker capable of carrying 2mn barrels of crude, and two smaller Suezmax-sized vessels with capacity of about 1mn barrels each.
The Atlantas is scheduled to head for European ports, the Monte Toledo for Spain and the Distya Akula for Constantza, Romania.
The loading operation of the three tankers at Kharg terminals will be done within 48 hours.
a6db5fef19bb2e5c69cc666897ec98d5:
Some reputable oil companies announced readiness to reimburse their unsettled payments immediately after sanctions were lifted.
The European debtors started their payments following opening of bank accounts.
Collection of the arrears started with small-scale debtors last week while some of them applied for arrangements which are being negotiated.
Royal-Dutch Shell and other European companies have started payment of their debts.
Emirates National Oil Company (ENOC) has taken due measures to pay back to the Central Bank of Iran.
If Babak Zanjani returns the Petroleum Ministry’s demands, his confiscated assets will not be sold.
0f395f9a6d6fae4e5086e898d1c956b4:
Greece is the third European customer to resume Iranian oil imports after France and Italy.
Greece demanded a daily average of 60,000 to 150,000 bpd Iranian oil.
Greece used to be Iranian customer to channel Iranian oil to refineries such as Hellenic Petroleum S.A.
Hellenic Petroleum S.A. is one of the largest oil companies in the Balkans and was established in 1958.
aac68711387066dcc2395f12f67831c4:
Iran plans to convert exported gas to LNG in Oman to access Far East Asian and European markets.
Using Oman's vacant LNG capacity is considered the best choice due to the high cost of building pipelines for gas export to Europe.
In March 2014, Tehran and Muscat agreed to lay pipelines for gas export, a project estimated to cost around 60 billion dollars.
Based on the Iran-Oman 2013 accord, Iran will export up to 20 million cubic meters of gas to Oman daily for 25 years through pipelines passing through the Persian Gulf bed.
Iranian gas will be transformed into LNG in Omani LNG facilities and then exported to world markets.
Iran has the capacity to use Oman's vacant capacity for production of 2.5 to 3 million tons of LNG.
6a9296545e805b1e55e9ffe0ca368e11:
Three million barrels of oil will be offloaded in Spain and other European ports for French company Total.
Oil consignment shipped to Romania will be delivered to Petrotel refinery in southern city of Ploiesti, which belongs to Russian Lukoil company.
Romania should renew its traditional economic ties with Iran's huge market and may export industrial equipment to Iran.
In 2015, trade exchange between Iran and Romania was 150 million dollars.
Four million barrels of Iranian crude oil are to be loaded on three oil tankers destined for Europe.
Two million barrels of Iranian crude oil had been purchased by Total company and other two million barrels by two Russian and Spanish firms.
6a7b68aa92618270660ed2b19dab7829:
Iran hopes to sign international oil deals worth $10 billion(Dh36.7 billion)-$15 billion by March next year.
The new model contract is still under development.
Iran hopes to attract international oil companies to invest in its oil sector and boost production.
A conference to unveil the new model contract has been repeatedly delayed due to international sanctions and domestic infighting.
50de0e467839c2a7ccf9da4df86b392f:
Greece is in preliminary talks with Iran to secure natural gas for local needs and provide a gateway for Iran to supply fuel to other parts of Europe.
Greece produces little oil and almost no gas, while Iran is a member of OPEC and holds gas reserves that BP Plc ranks as the world's largest.
In January, Iran agreed to supply crude to Hellenic Petroleum SA and buy oil products from the refiner.
Iran is interested in using the Revythousa re-gasification terminal near Athens and a planned facility at Alexandroupolis in the north of Greece to export gas to Europe.
Iran lacks facilities to export LNG but wants to use idle capacity at a facility in neighboring Oman to process raw gas into a liquefied form for sale.
Iran and Oman are negotiating to build a pipeline to send gas across the Persian Gulf to the Omani facility.
Iranian companies have expressed interest in participating with Depa, Greece's state-run gas supplier, in a company that will build and run the planned floating LNG storage and re-gasification facility at Alexandroupolis.
The expansion of the Revythousa gas-importing terminal will be completed in 2017 and could send gas northward to other areas in Europe with adequate investment.
Both the Revythousa and Alexandroupolis facilities will be connected to two international pipeline systems, the planned Trans Adriatic Pipeline and Gas Interconnector Greece-Bulgaria links.
Iran is also interested in Greece's refineries, but the Greek government has no plans to reduce its 35 percent share in Hellenic Petroleum, the country's biggest refiner.
fd5c81e80fe3a5ee0be0359e2a897d25:
Iran exported about 760,000 metric tons of fuel in January.
100,000 metric tons of Iran's exported fuel reached Singapore in January.
About 50% of Iran's exported fuel will enter Fujairah market.
Iran's fuel exported last January shows 81% growth compared to previous year.
Singapore is predicted to import around 5 million metric tons of fuel from various sources.
Increasing Iranian fuel exports will lead to decreasing the oil price.
3c01b4e76d55a68c1420583139f27732:
Iran's oil and gas condensates export increased by 400,000 barrels per day in February compared to the same period the previous year.
South Korea currently imports 100,000 barrels of crude per day from Iran, and it is expected to double.
South Korean companies were active in Iran's oil and gas industries before sanctions.
South Korean officials have promised to increase imports of crude oil and gas condensates from Iran to a level higher than before sanctions.
South Korea and Iran have agreed that South Korea will invest and finance projects in Iran's LNG, petrochemical, refining, and distribution industries.
Iran considers South Korea a major Asian partner and a potential customer for its oil and LNG.
South Korean President is scheduled to visit Iran in May with a large commercial and economic delegation.
South Korea, China, Japan, and Turkey were purchasers of Iranian crude during the sanction era.
283f55d74be68619b0a5f8a66981ef15:
Pakistan is considering allowing oil imports from Iran via land route after the lifting of international sanctions.
Pakistan stopped oil import through land route about six years ago due to UN and US sanctions on Tehran.
Iran is capable of exporting crude oil in big volumes.
Two Pakistani refineries had been importing Iranian crude until 2010 but after the sanctions banks refused to open letters of credit for oil purchases.
Pakistan’s law enforcement agencies have sealed a 500km belt along the border to check smuggling of goods, particularly petroleum products.
Oil has a dominant place among the smuggled goods for decades.
Pakistan is hoping to open banking channels in June this year, which will also lead to the opening of land route for oil supply from Iran.
Pakistan's oil demand stands at 22 million tons per year, with local refineries producing 13 million tons and the remaining imported.
Pakistan State Oil is a major oil supplier and importer.
Local refineries meet 45% of demand for high-speed diesel, 35-40% of need for petrol and 30-35% of demand for furnace oil.
Pakistan is currently importing crude oil from the United Arab Emirates (UAE) and Saudi Arabia.
52af5b3b48e1e4dbc830fb3d6a569109:
Georgia has signed an agreement with Azerbaijan's state oil company SOCAR to increase natural gas supply by 463 million cubic meters.
Georgia no longer needs to import gas from Iran after signing the agreement with SOCAR.
Georgia had previously started talks with Iran due to technical problems regarding the natural gas supply from Azerbaijan.
SOCAR will ensure the natural gas supply to Georgia and meet the market's needs.
Azerbaijan will reduce prices for the gas sold at social tariffs, as well as the commercially sold gas.
4021082c0d63ba0838addedb45ea49f0: Iran expects economic growth of more than 5 percent in 2016 after the lifting of sanctions.
Iran emerged from years of economic isolation in January when world powers lifted crippling sanctions against Iran.
c8e6d5867a06723580868063b2bb48d1:
The Monte Toledo oil tanker delivered 1 million barrels of Iranian crude to Europe, the first such delivery since mid-2012.
The delivery marks the end of an oil embargo imposed by Brussels in an attempt to force Iran to negotiate the end of its nuclear program.
Iran's President Hassan Rouhani declared that more oil exports "will be added soon" and that exports will "soon return" to 2 million barrels a day.
Other tankers with Iranian oil are close behind the Monte Toledo, with three heading toward Europe.
Iran exported about 1.4 million barrels a day in February, up 350,000 barrels a day from the average 2015 level.
Iran is facing hurdles in winning back customers in Europe, where other suppliers stepped in after the embargo was imposed.
The US has started exporting crude and is shipping American oil into refineries in the Mediterranean.
Before the embargo, Europe imported on average about 400,000 barrels a day of oil from Iran.
If all goes as Tehran has planned, Iran will boost its production back to the 3.6 million barrels a day it pumped in 2011.
8c3e65ea6dfafa4869de5d2d7d519ccc:
On April 17, Palestinian Prisoners' Day was commemorated with almost 2,500 Palestinians and Arabs remaining in Israeli prisons and detention centers.
Palestinian and Arab prisoners in Israel continue to suffer difficult living conditions, denied basic rights, and subjected to torture during interrogation.
Almost 100 prisoners are held without charge or trial under administrative detention.
Israel continues to deprive prisoners of the right to receive legal aid by prohibiting Palestinian lawyers from visiting them.
Palestinian prisoners are also deprived of the right to receive regular family visits in a decent and humane way.
Many prisoners suffer from deteriorating health conditions as Israel does not provide proper medical treatment.
Israel continues to disregard appeals from human rights and international humanitarian organizations to release prisoners in critical health conditions or to provide them with proper medical care to save their lives.
Many Palestinian prisoners are isolated in individual cells and subjected to oppressive measures threatening their lives.
Israel continues to practice different methods of torture against Palestinian and Arab prisoners despite international and local condemnation.
Israel is the only country worldwide to have legalized torture, apparently in a conspiracy between the judicial, legislative, and executive branches of the government.
On December 11, 1998, the Israeli daily Yerushaleim published that the head of the Israeli General Security Services (Shabak) admitted that no interrogator from the Shabak had not used torture.
PCHR calls for the international community to exert pressure on Israel to release Palestinian and Arab prisoners, particularly the elderly, the ill, and juveniles.
PCHR calls for bringing all those involved in the perpetration of torture to justice.
PCHR calls for providing proper medical aid for ill prisoners or to outright release them.
PCHR calls for guaranteeing that all prisoners are able to receive regular and humane family visits.
PCHR calls for allowing Palestinian lawyers to visit Israeli prisons in order to provide legal aid to Palestinian and Arab prisoners.
19cb46d7daea0ca1a3fda39a01542d80:
Palestinian journalist Mohammed al-Qiq is in poor health after nearly 50 days on hunger strike.
Mohammed al-Qiq's wife said that he is vomiting blood and has lost 25 kilograms (55 pounds).
Mohammed al-Qiq was arrested on November 21 at his home in the West Bank city of Ramallah and in mid-December placed under administrative detention.
Mohammed al-Qiq began a hunger strike on November 25, alleging torture by his captors.
Mohammed al-Qiq is currently in the hospital wing of Ramle prison, in central Israel.
Mohammed al-Qiq was jailed in 2008 for 16 months for student activism which Israel says was linked to Islamist militant group Hamas.
f87527a0f153da38aca86205b8591afd:
Israeli forces applied the force-feeding law against administrative detainee and journalist Mohammed al-Qeeq, who has been on a hunger strike for about 50 days.
Al-Qeeq was handcuffed and then forcibly administrated intravenous fluids.
The Palestinian Center for Human Rights (PCHR) is gravely concerned over the risks that may result from force-feeding al-Qeeq.
PCHR calls upon the international community to promptly intervene to save his life and stop force-feeding.
Mohammed Usamah al-Qeeq (33) has been on an open hunger strike since 25 November 2015 in protest against placing him under 6-month administrative detention.
Al-Qeeq has since refused to eat or undergo medical tests, so his health status deteriorated.
Al-Qeeq was taken to al-Afoulah Hospital in Israel and is still there, as his health condition is getting worse.
Human rights sources reported that he suffers from permanent headache and pains in the stomach and joints, vomits blood and lost 13 kilograms.
On 21 November 2015, Al-Qeeq, Correspondent at al-Majd Saudi Channel, was arrested from his house in Ramallah.
He was then subjected to tough interrogation, during which he was exposed to torture, including shackling (Shabeh), before being placed under administrative detention.
PCHR is concerned over the life of Mohammed al-Qeeq.
PCHR calls upon the international community to pressurize the Israeli forces to stop all attempts to forcibly feed him fearing for his life.
PCHR reiterates its call upon the international community to urgently move to stop the Israeli serious and systematic abuses against the Palestinian detainees in the Israeli prisons.
PCHR emphasizes that administrative detention is illegal and falls under the category of political arrests, constituting a violation of the detainee’s right to a fair trial, including his right to receive an adequate defense and to be informed of the charges against him.
PCHR stresses that the force-feeding is considered as a form of torture and degrading treatment under the international law.
d337e52eefc46b1062e3ba831ac0c6c6:
Palestinian journalist Muhammed al-Qeq is in critical condition after 50 days of hunger strike in protest of his six-month detention without trial in an Israeli prison.
Al-Qeq's father says he is "about to die now" and "vomits and urinates blood."
Al-Qeq was arrested by Israel's Shin Bet security service on November 21 and accused of links to Hamas.
Al-Qeq's wife says he was subjected to "inhuman and degrading treatment" in an Israeli detention center, including beatings, insults, and threats of sexual assault.
Al-Qeq's family believes he was detained because he described the Israelis as an occupying force committing crimes against humanity in the West Bank.
e580b12b8172da71e36c64a7ea841514:
Palestinian Centre for Human Rights (PCHR) demands the immediate release of Jamal Hassan Al-Khamisi, a Palestinian prisoner detained since September 1989.
Jamal Hassan Al-Khamisi is sentenced to 25 years imprisonment in Israel.
Jamal Hassan Al-Khamisi is suffering from cancer of the liver and is expected to live for just 4 more months.
6a05385c673623b71efd0a8bfdb8442e:
Meir Ettinger, grandson of slain far-right activist Meir Kahane, has gone on a hunger strike to protest his administrative detention.
Ettinger was placed in detention on Aug. 15 for “involvement in violent activities and terrorist attacks that occurred recently, and his role as part of a Jewish terrorist group,” according to Israeli authorities.
His arrest was linked to the firebombing of a home in the West Bank Palestinian village of Duma that left an infant and his parents dead.
Shin Bet officials have said Ettinger heads a movement that also was responsible for the June arson of the historic Church of the Multiplication of the Loaves and Fishes, and seeks to bring down the government and replace it with a Jewish theocracy.
Attorney General Yehuda Weinstein approved the order for a six-month detention issued by Defense Minister Moshe Yaalon against Ettinger.
The Lod District Court in mid-September upheld the order.
Under administrative detention, which is more commonly used for Palestinian prisoners, one can be held for six months without being charged or tried. The order can be renewed indefinitely.
Ettinger does not have American citizenship.
bb2da404c6f029c69e584a4ec1e12238:
The ICRC monitors the health and well-being of hunger strikers in Israel and Palestine.
The ICRC ensures that the rights, dignity, and physical integrity of hunger strikers are respected.
The ICRC encourages communication between hunger strikers, their representatives, and authorities to find solutions that avoid loss of life.
ICRC medical doctors assess the medical condition of hunger strikers and provide independent medical advice.
The ICRC opposes forced feeding or treatment of hunger strikers, considering it a violation of medical ethics and international humanitarian law.
3f0c8f5131a8a36f6d0391e4aed59769:
Amnesty International urges Israel to release Palestinian journalist Mohammed al-Qiq, who is on a hunger strike and in critical condition.
Qiq has been held without charge or trial under Israel's administrative detention since November 21, 2015.
Qiq has been on hunger strike since November 25.
Amnesty International demands that Israel cease all non-consensual medical treatment and other punitive measures against Qiq.
Amnesty International demands that Israel conduct an independent investigation into allegations of torture against Qiq.
Physicians for Human Rights-Israel (PHR-Israel) reports that Israeli authorities have force-treated Qiq, which is a violation of international law.
PHR-Israel calls upon doctors and medics at HaEmek Hospital in Afula to stop force-treating Qiq.
The World Medical Association, the Red Cross, and the United Nations consider force-feeding a cruel, inhuman, and degrading treatment or punishment, and a flagrant violation of international law.
Administrative detention is an illegal scheme devised by Israel under which Palestinian inmates are kept in Israeli detention facilities without trial or charge.
More than 7,000 Palestinians are reportedly being held in 17 Israeli prisons and detention centers.
ea2b824aa8f510a57451e09ebddff628:
Palestinian journalist Muhammad al-Qiq is on the brink of death after 61 days of hunger strike in Israeli jail.
Al-Qiq is unconscious and cannot speak, exhibiting "sudden symptoms that could lead to his death."
Israel is accused of “reckless and indifferent treatment of al-Qiq,” which stems from “a decision by the extremist Israeli government and its intelligence to let him die.”
Al-Qiq has been on hunger strike since Nov. 24 to protest his administrative detention -- internment without trial or charge.
Amnesty International reported that the military judge at the Ofer Military Court said the file against al-Qiq “accuses him of ‘incitement,’ of working with media associated with Hamas, and also of being a ‘threat to the security of the area.’"
Amnesty International demanded that Israel either release or charge al-Qiq, who the group said has been mistreated and tortured in ways that violate international law.
Physicians for Human Rights Israel (PHRI) said doctors in HaEmek Hospital in Afula were "forcing treatment upon (al-Qiq) and pressuring him to end his hunger strike."
PHRI called on doctors to stop the "forced treatment" and respect international human rights law, which says hunger strikers cannot be forced or pressured to intake food or supplements.
71 UK doctors have called on the World Medical Association to expel the Israeli Medical Association from the body, claiming that Israeli doctors have carried out “medical torture” on Palestinians.
f0625b58f9d570bd569f23e2b55e2978:
Palestinian journalist Mohammed al-Qiq, who has been on a two-month-long hunger strike in an Israeli jail, could die at any minute.
Qiq, a 33-year-old father of two and a correspondent for Saudi Arabia’s Almajd TV network, was arrested on November 21 of last year at his home in the West Bank city of Ramallah and is being held under Israel’s controversial administrative detention measure.
Qiq has been refusing food since November 25 in protest over the “torture and ill-treatment that he was subjected to during interrogation.”
After 61 days since his strike began, Qiq’s organs are said to be at risk of failure.
The Shin Bet, Israel’s domestic security service, alleges Qiq is an active member of the Islamist terror group Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip.
Qiq was transferred to hospital in the Israeli city of Afula about a month ago.
A controversial Israeli law passed in July allows the force-feeding of prisoners in certain circumstances, though it has yet to be invoked.
Top Palestinian Authority official Saeb Erekat told AFP that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu “personally bears responsibility for al-Qiq’s life.”
30187ebce4e44f7d097af34751d0203a:
The PLO has called for the unconditional release of Palestinian journalist Muhammad al-Qiq, who has been on a 62-day hunger strike in protest of his administrative detention in Israeli prison.
The Israeli Supreme Court is set to hear an appeal for al-Qiq’s release on Wednesday at 11:30 a.m.
Al-Qiq’s lawyers will speak out against his administrative detention, under which hundreds of Palestinian political detainees are currently being held.
The Palestinian Authority’s Committee for Prisoners’ Affairs warned that any further deterioration of al-Qiq’s health or his potential death could have far-reaching consequences for Israel politically, including popular unrest among Palestinians held in Israeli prisons.
Some 45 Palestinian prisoners affiliated to the leftist Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP) being held in the Megiddo and Gilboa prisons began a two-day strike Tuesday in an act of solidarity with al-Qiq.
6da0c942316dc3e4600fd0b767722459:
Scores of Hamas detainees have been on hunger strike in Palestinian prisons for three consecutive days.
The hunger-striking prisoners protest against their illegal and unjust detention.
The Palestinian Centre for Human Rights has not been permitted to visit the hunger-striking prisoners.
The prison administration will only permit access when a permit is granted by President Arafat or the Police Chief Ghazi Jabali.
The Palestinian Centre for Human Rights is seeking special permission from the Attorney-General to visit the prisoners.
Some 50 detainees affiliated to Hamas began an open-ended hunger strike on Sunday 12 October 1997.
The security forces separated the hunger-strikers and moved them to smaller cells.
Ten hunger-strikers were moved to Police Headquarters in Gaza City, and two were moved to the Preventive Security headquarters.
The Palestinian Centre for Human Rights warns of the deterioration of the conditions and health of the Hamas detainees.
The Palestinian National Authority is called upon to release the Hamas detainees and respect human rights and the rule of law.
The Palestinian National Authority should resist pressure from foreign governments, particularly the United States and Israel, to violate the human rights of the Palestinian people.
On 15 August 1997, 11 prisoners were released upon an order by the Attorney-General Fayez Abu Rahmah but were re-detained three hours later by Palestinian security services.
The Palestinian Legislative Council and Palestinian human rights groups have asked for the release of all these prisoners or for them to be brought before a court for a fair trial.
The Palestinian Centre for Human Rights believes that the Palestinian National Authority should respect the rule of law and human rights in Palestine.
5e26e47011e0543934b0551f151c9071:
Israel's Supreme Court ruled that Palestinian hunger striker Mohammed al-Qiq will remain in jail despite his deteriorating health.
Qiq has been on hunger strike for 63 days over his detention under Israel's administrative detention law.
The European Union expressed concern about Qiq's health, as experts say the risk of death grows daily after 50 days of hunger strike.
Qiq's lawyer requested his release, but the court ruled that Qiq "constitutes a danger to the security of Israel" based on classified material presented by the Shin Bet security services.
Qiq was arrested on November 21 for "terror activity" as a member of Hamas, which he denies.
Over 680 Palestinians are currently under administrative detention in Israeli prisons, out of 6,800 in total.
4365963d6524d5a044b6a32a8606f2e2:
The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) warns that Palestinian prisoner Mohammed al-Qiq's life is "at risk" after 64 days of hunger strike.
Al-Qiq, a 33-year-old journalist, was arrested in November 2021 and accused of "terror activity" involving Hamas.
Al-Qiq denies the charges and began the hunger strike after facing torture during interrogation.
The ICRC urges al-Qiq's Israeli captors to "find a solution that will avoid any loss of life."
Al-Qiq's wife, Faihaa, argues that he was arrested for covering the situation in the West Bank.
Over 160 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli forces since October 2015.
Israel's Supreme Court overturned al-Qiq's appeal against his incarceration on Wednesday.
The European Union expresses "concern" about al-Qiq's deteriorating health.
Israeli forces carried out 574 attacks against reporters in the past year, including detentions, extension of detention periods, and subpoenas.
155a74ca99d8a7f008c3daa1c8464094:
UN official Robert Piper expressed alarm over the deteriorating health of Palestinian journalist Mohammed al-Qiq, who is on a 70-day hunger strike in protest of his detention without trial.
Mohammed al-Qiq, a 33-year-old father of two and a correspondent for Saudi Arabia's Almajd television network, was arrested on November 21 at his home in the West Bank city of Ramallah.
Qiq has been refusing food since November 25 in protest of his detention under Israel's administrative detention law, which allows the state to hold suspects for renewable six-month periods without trial.
Shin Bet, the Israeli domestic security service, says Qiq was arrested for "terror activity" as part of the Islamist group Hamas.
His family deny the claims and say he was only a journalist covering the West Bank.
76d615b44885f4012b586eedd060a621:
Israel's Supreme Court suspended the detention without trial of Palestinian journalist Mohammed al-Qiq, who has been on hunger strike for more than two months.
Mohammed al-Qiq cannot leave hospital without permission.
Mohammed al-Qiq was arrested on November 21 at his home in the West Bank city of Ramallah.
Mohammed al-Qiq has been refusing food since November 25 in protest against the "torture and ill treatment that he was subjected to during interrogation".
The International Committee of the Red Cross said last week that Mohammed al-Qiq's life was in danger.
Shin Bet, the Israeli domestic security service, says Mohammed al-Qiq was arrested for "terror activity" as part of the Islamist group Hamas.
2152f49584bf235798bae075610114fe:
Palestinian prisoner Muhammad al-Qiq rejected an Israeli court decision to temporarily suspend his detention without trial and will continue his hunger strike that is now in its 72nd day.
Al-Qiq views the court ruling as an attempt to undermine his resistance against Israel's internment of Palestinians without trial or charge.
Al-Qiq will not end his hunger strike unless Israel agrees to his full release.
Al-Qiq is refusing to receive medical treatment unless at a Palestinian hospital.
The Israeli Supreme Court suspended al-Qiq's six-month administrative detention sentence citing medical concerns, with the sentence to be resumed upon an improvement of his health.
Qadura Fares, the head of the Palestinian Prisoner's Society, decried it as a "bad decision."
Al-Qiq has said he will continue his hunger strike until "martyrdom or freedom."
Al-Qiq is now in critical condition and only able to communicate by written messages.
Dr. Mahmoud Mahamid, a member of Physicians for Human Rights Israel, found al-Qiq "at imminent risk of death" during a visit on Thursday morning.
Al-Qiq initially went on hunger strike in late November to protest the torture and ill-treatment he said he faced in Israeli custody.
Al-Qiq's protest has developed into another bid to challenge Israel's use of administrative detention.
The Palestinian Prisoner's Society has said that Israel's security establishment has so far shown little willingness to negotiate on al-Qiq's release.
5a853549a23c851bdc96e37934643c4f:
Ailing Palestinian journalist Mohammed al-Qiq will continue his 75-day hunger strike, rejecting an Israeli offer to release him by May 1.
Qiq demands to be released immediately and have a complete end to his administrative detention.
Qiq is reportedly close to death and has already suffered permanent damage due to the lengthy hunger strike.
Israel’s Supreme Court lifted the order to hold Qiq under administrative detention law, but he still cannot leave the hospital without permission.
Qiq remains handcuffed to his bed in HaEmek Medical Center in Afula.
A senior Hamas official abroad said that if anything happens to Qiq, or he dies, it will lead to an escalation of violence.
Qiq was arrested on November 21 at his home in the West Bank city of Ramallah for “terror activity” as part of Hamas.
c4c8a9357c3aec2337ee43a30b0492a2:
Mohammad Allan, a former Palestinian hunger striker, explains that hunger strikes are a last resort for Palestinian prisoners facing humiliation, torture, and an unjust court system in Israeli detention.
Mohammad Al Qeq, a journalist, is currently on a hunger strike after being imprisoned under administrative detention without formal charges or evidence.
The Israeli Supreme Court suspended Al Qeq's detention order but prohibited him from leaving the hospital, where he is shackled to his bed.
Al Qeq and other hunger strikers are using their bodies as a voice to protest the Israeli occupation and demand freedom for Palestinian prisoners.
Hunger strikes in Israeli prisons involve solitary confinement, denial of basic necessities, and psychological warfare.
The physical toll of hunger strikes includes hair loss, nausea, pain, vomiting, headaches, and skin fissures.
Former hunger strikers emphasize that their actions are not for personal gain but represent the collective struggle of the Palestinian people against oppression.
Notable Palestinian hunger strikers include Samir Issawi, Mahmoud Sarsak, Thaer Halahleh, and Bilal Thiab.
776573f5dcfdcd91832b3f7296624e4d:
Palestinian journalist Mohamed al-Qeeq is on the brink of death after 81 days of hunger strike in an Israeli jail.
Al-Qeeq has lost almost 60 kilograms and suffers chest pain, muscle cramps and significant increases in body temperature.
Al-Qeeq rejected an Israeli court decision to remove him from administrative detention and will maintain his hunger strike until his unconditional release.
Al-Qeeq's wife, Fayha Shalash, has called on Palestinian political factions to save her husband's life.
Al-Qeeq, 32, was arrested by Israel on Nov. 24 of last year for alleged "incitement" and has been detained without trial.
4df26c6aaca9b1cf9556edad92c07828:
Palestinian journalist Mohammed al-Qiq has rejected a compromise to transfer him to a hospital in East Jerusalem, demanding instead to be sent to a Palestinian medical facility.
Al-Qiq, who is on hunger strike to protest his detention in Israel without charge, is currently being treated at Haemek hospital in Afula, Israel.
The High Court rejected Al-Qiq's request to be transferred to a hospital in Ramallah, under Palestinian control, and instead recommended he be sent to the Arab-run al-Makassed hospital in East Jerusalem.
The court's decision states that the move is "within the framework of the frozen administrative measures concerning him," raising the possibility that Al-Qiq could be detained again if he ends his hunger strike.
Al-Qiq, 33, is reported to be close to death after 83 days of a hunger strike.
Administrative detention allows the state to hold suspects without trial for periods of six months, which can be renewed indefinitely.
The Shin Bet security service says Qiq was detained for terrorist activity on behalf of Palestinian terror group Hamas.
Al-Qiq's internment was officially suspended on February 4, but he has still been prevented from leaving the Afula hospital where he is handcuffed to his bed.
Al-Qiq was arrested at his home in Ramallah on November 21 and has been refusing food since November 25.
The United Nations has expressed concern about Al-Qiq's fate, while the International Committee of the Red Cross describes his condition as critical.
796ea1108db182832344d3c03aa54211:
The World Health Organization West Bank and Gaza office expresses extreme concern over the life and welfare of Palestinian administrative detainee Mohamed Qiq, who is on an 85-day hunger strike to protest his detention without trial.
Mohamed Qiq remains in the care of an Israeli hospital where his wishes against taking nutrition are being respected.
In 2015, WHO joined a joint UN statement against the force-feeding of hunger strikers and emphasized the importance of improving health and human rights conditions of Palestinian prisoners in line with international standards.
WHO urges all parties to resolve this issue according to the universal principles of human rights.
8e81919bcea6810627606b49f40f4347:
Palestinian journalist Mohammed al-Qiq is close to death after 87 days of hunger strike in protest of his detention without charge for 'terror activity' in Israel.
Al-Qiq has lost nearly half his body weight and is on the verge of organ failure after only consuming tap water and occasionally minerals and vitamins.
Al-Qiq has been refusing food since November 25 in protest against the 'torture and ill treatment that he was subjected to during interrogation' by Israeli security services.
Israel's Shin Bet domestic security service says Qiq was detained for 'terror activity' on behalf of the Islamist group Hamas, which controls the Gaza Strip.
The Supreme Court officially suspended the internment order against Qiq on February 4 but refused his demand for transfer to a hospital in the West Bank city of Ramallah, under Palestinian Authority jurisdiction.
The court offered a compromise whereby he would be moved to the Palestinian-run Makassed hospital in Israeli-annexed east Jerusalem, but Qiq turned down the proposal.
Arab Israeli Islamic cleric Raed Salah and others have started an open-ended hunger strike in solidarity with Qiq.
bc2dc9e8d262fe65e42c34a32f114536:
Palestinian journalist Mohammed al-Qiq is on the 85th day of a hunger strike against his administrative detention.
Al-Qiq has refused to end his hunger strike despite his administrative detention being suspended by Israel's supreme court.
Al-Qiq is determined to be treated at Ramallah Hospital, not Afula, because Israeli forces regularly enter the Palestinian Makassed Hospital in East Jerusalem to arrest patients.
Al-Qiq's doctor believes his case is unusual because he has refused to take a saline drink or medical examinations.
A handful of supporters are on their second day of a hunger strike in solidarity with al-Qiq, led by Shiekh Raed Salah.
Salah warned that there would be a strong "backlash" if al-Qiq died.
